property.name: text
property.value:
#1. WebServer accessor with app logic at the same hierarchy level.
responseID is transmitted as part of data flow. Routing is explicitly shown.

property.name: text
property.value: Ideas on how to architect a web server and web services using accessors. This model is not intended to run.

property.name: text
property.value: AppLogic1 includes requestID as part of its response.

property.name: text
property.value: LibraryAccessor is unaware of requestIDs. requestID must be propagated separately. (Or, LibraryAccessor must be modified somehow).

property.name: text
property.value:
#2. WebService composite refinement.
WebService is a library accessor that contains the app logic and takes care of requestID propagation. The app logic does not need to be aware of the requestID. WebService could also offer standardized response creation (both error and normal). Custom responses are also possible. Routing is explicit as in #1.

property.name: text
property.value: Open me!

property.name: text
property.value: Open me!

property.name: text
property.value:
#3. WebSource accessor, implementing webServer as a module.
WebSource is an accessor that require()s a webServer module and registers a path with this module. Routing is implicit. The module hides responseIDs and offers standardized response creation (both error and normal). Custom responses are also possible.
WebSource is similar to HttpActor. (Minus the festival of output ports).
We would probably want some way to configure server properties e.g. default timeout, port. (Similar to the WebServer attribute in Ptolemy).

property.name: text
property.value: I have a path property!

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

property.name: description
property.value:
This accessor starts a server that listens for HTTP requests on the specified hostInterface and port and issues responses. The hostInterface specifies what network interface (e.g. Ethernet, WiFi, or localhost) to use. The default is 'localhost', which (usually) means that the server listens only for requests coming from the local machine. This is useful for testing. To listen for requests on all IPv4 addresses on the local machine, specify '0.0.0.0'. This will make the server accessible to any machine that has access to an IP address for the local machine.

When this server receives an http requests from the network (or from the local machine), it produces a JavaScript object on the output that includes at least the following properties:

  • body: The body of the request, or null if there is no body.
  • method: A string that describes the HTTP method of the request, which may be "GET", "PUT", etc.
  • path: The path in the URL of the request, such as "/" when there is no path.
  • requestID: An identifier for the request.

To produce a response, this accessor waits for an input on its response port that is a JavaScript object containing the following properties:

  • requestID: An identifier matching a request for which a response has not already been issued.
  • response: The body of the response, such as HTML to display to the requester or a JavaScript object with a JSON representation (the JSON representation will be sent back as the response). If this property is not included in the input, then the input will be stringified as a JSON object and sent. This will include the requestID property.

If there is no pending request with a matching ID, then an error will be issued.

A simple use case is to connect the request output to some other actor that generates a response, and then to feed that response back to the response input. Be sure to include the requestID property in the response.

When wrapup() is invoked, this accessor closes the server.

This accessor requires the module httpServer.

property.name: author
property.value: Edward A. Lee amd Elizabeth Osyk

property.name: response (port)
property.value: The response to issue to a request.

property.name: listening (port)
property.value: When the server is listening for connections, this output will produce the port number that the server is listening on

property.name: request (port)
property.value: The request that came into the server.

property.name: hostInterface (parameter)
property.value: The IP address or domain name of the network interface to listen to.

property.name: port (parameter)
property.value: The port to listen on.

property.name: shutdown (port)
property.value: Shutdown the web server.

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

This accessor starts a server that listens for HTTP requests on the specified hostInterface and port and issues responses. The hostInterface specifies what network interface (e.g. Ethernet, WiFi, or localhost) to use. The default is 'localhost', which (usually) means that the server listens only for requests coming from the local machine. This is useful for testing. To listen for requests on all IPv4 addresses on the local machine, specify '0.0.0.0'. This will make the server accessible to any machine that has access to an IP address for the local machine.

When this server receives an http requests from the network (or from the local machine), it produces a JavaScript object on the output that includes at least the following properties:

  • body: The body of the request, or null if there is no body.
  • method: A string that describes the HTTP method of the request, which may be "GET", "PUT", etc.
  • path: The path in the URL of the request, such as "/" when there is no path.
  • requestID: An identifier for the request.

To produce a response, this accessor waits for an input on its response port that is a JavaScript object containing the following properties:

  • requestID: An identifier matching a request for which a response has not already been issued.
  • response: The body of the response, such as HTML to display to the requester or a JavaScript object with a JSON representation (the JSON representation will be sent back as the response). If this property is not included in the input, then the input will be stringified as a JSON object and sent. This will include the requestID property.

If there is no pending request with a matching ID, then an error will be issued.

A simple use case is to connect the request output to some other actor that generates a response, and then to feed that response back to the response input. Be sure to include the requestID property in the response.

When wrapup() is invoked, this accessor closes the server.

This accessor requires the module httpServer.

property.name: text
property.value:
WebService will internally strip off the requestID at the input, remember it, then append it to the response data for output.
It could also offer standardized response page and error page creation.

property.name: text
property.value:
Library accessors can be used without modification.
WebService will internally strip off the requestID at the input, remember it, then append it to the response data for output.
It could also offer standardized response page and error page creation.
